claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling, creating an inflammatory tumor microenvironment.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units) | 3.1 | 1.0 | Marked induction after mRNA vaccination in tumors
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: The interferon response was measured using a normalized scoring system, and the strength of this effect varied across different mouse model systems rather than being uniform.

claims.claim: mRNA vaccination expands the repertoire of tumor antigens presented on MHC-I molecules, improving tumor visibility to cytotoxic T cells.

evidence.quote: Fraction of proteins represented in MHC-I peptidome | 40.6% | 20.6% | Strong expansion of MHC-I-presented landscape
Fraction of tumor proteins represented in immunopeptidome | 62.3% | 37.3% | Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination

claims.caveat: These findings were derived from immunopeptidomics in preclinical models; human translation of antigen presentation changes was not directly measured.

claims.claim: Combined intratumoral mRNA vaccination and anti-PD-L1 therapy produces superior tumor control compared to either monotherapy in mouse models.

evidence.quote: PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue | 2.4x | 1.0x | Checkpoint axis became more targetable
Intratumoral CD8+ T-cell density fold-change | 1.8x | 1.0x | Increased immune infiltration with combination therapy

claims.caveat: The efficacy data comes from preclinical mouse models; human combination therapy trials have not been conducted to confirm translatability.

claims.claim: Prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination is associated with improved survival outcomes in metastatic cancer patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor treatment.

evidence.quote: Retrospective human survival comparison p-value | p=0.01 | Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment
Human metastatic cohort: 130 patients total | Human vaccinated subgroup: 43 patients | Human unvaccinated subgroup: 87 patients

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective, non-randomized, and subject to confounding factors including variable vaccination timing and heterogeneous tumor types and treatment histories.
